instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message: Hi guys, so I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with liquid spil near <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and I need to replace 5 resistors with corrosion. One of the resistor is <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR> which has a hole in the board on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR_VDD</SIGNAL>). This is actually not a resistor I can replace it just shows two solder points. The resistor is 0 ohm, can i just jumpwire this or how to go about? Attached an image for reference with the location.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage
threads.message:
Have you checked the CPU rails and compare to working board. Dead CPU is of course very likely before you put any more time into this.
<RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR> is no stuff on diagram, so it is probably not there. If <RESISTOR>R7224</RESISTOR> is present then <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR> will of course not be there!
